title: 113_hr1582
content: The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013" prohibits the Environmental Protection Agency from finalizing energy-related rules estimated to cost over $1 billion if they will have significant adverse effects on the economy. Prior reports and determinations are required before such rules can be finalized. Before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with details on the rule, total costs, benefits, and uncertainties. Before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with details on the rule, total costs, benefits, and uncertainties. The report should include an estimate of the total benefits of the rule, a description of the modeling and calculations used, and a certification that all data relied upon by the Agency is available for public review on the Agency's website. The EPA must provide Congress with details on energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, including estimates of energy price increases and employment effects resulting from the rule's implementation or enforcement. Data and documents supporting the estimates are available for public review on the Agency's website. The EPA must report to Congress on energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, including estimates of energy price increases and employment effects. The Secretary of Energy will conduct an independent analysis to determine the rule's impact on energy prices for consumers and fuel diversity. The Secretary of Energy will conduct an independent analysis to determine the impact of the rule on energy prices, fuel diversity, electric reliability, and energy supply. The Secretary of Energy will analyze the rule's impact on energy prices, fuel diversity, electric reliability, and supply. If adverse effects are found, a subsequent determination on the economy will be made in consultation with other agencies. The Secretary of Energy will analyze the rule's impact on energy prices, fuel diversity, electric reliability, and supply. If adverse effects are found, a subsequent determination on the economy will be made in consultation with other agencies to assess significant adverse effects on the economy caused by the rule. This includes considering costs, benefits, economic indicators, and impacts on GDP, unemployment, wages, consumer prices, and business activity. The Secretary of Energy will analyze the rule's impact on energy prices, fuel diversity, electric reliability, and supply. A subsequent determination on the economy will be made, considering costs, benefits, and economic indicators like GDP, unemployment, wages, consumer prices, and business activity. Results will be published in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "direct costs" and "indirect costs" are defined as per the Environmental Protection Agency's guidelines. The term "energy-related rule that is estimated to cost more than $1 billion" refers to a rule regulating aspects of energy production with estimated costs exceeding $1 billion. The term "rule" refers to regulation by States or governmental entities with estimated costs exceeding $1 billion. SEC. 5. PROHIBITION ON USE OF SOCIAL COST OF CARBON IN ANALYSIS. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, unless authorized by Federal law. The term "social cost of carbon" refers to a specific document or any related estimate. The House of Representatives passed a bill on August 1, 2013, related to monetized damages from increased carbon dioxide emissions. Karen L. Haas attested to the bill.
